4:08 sqlite was slower for me, so I use postgres
"squeel server"  cringe......
12:00 Team Foundations Server is actually terrible. We finally stopped using where I work about a month ago
TFS was a dream compared to visual source safe

Why not dump the whole MSSQL setup onto LevelDB and call it a day, that beauty is able to easily absorb 4608 columns like its nothing, you can give it a million columns and it would happily take them!!

MSSQL is so old and crappy that it now shows its age and bugs for everyone to see clearly!!!

0:52 You missed that this was a slightly different topic. It's not saying don't have 1024 columns in the underlying table, it's don't have more that 1024 columns in a pivot. If you do 'select a,b,c from table' you can instead return it as a row for each a, with a column for each b, and the field value being c, like a spreadsheet. If which case, they're recommending to keep the distinct values of b to < 1024.
I relate to Gilfoyle. So many one off apps I built for individuals that asked me for features over the years.
normalize your tables
9:04 I can just imagine ChatGPT being asked for code and spitting out a 1500 like script

If you use more than 30 columns, you're doing it wrong. In 15 years of database design, only three or four times did I have a need to go beyond 15. Very subtle events. they were.

And, god dammit, use more indexes!!!!!!!!!!

I can relate to the direct to customer part. I was pulled into a call by a customer service guy who's trying to solve the customer's problem of opening our site. And I was a devops team member and didn't know how and why they find me for support. But hey, I'm happy to help. So we used teamviewer to try to find the problem. After some fiddling, everything seems normal. I suspect it's the anti-virus software he installed stopped the browser from accessing our site. But he insist he didn't put the site to blacklist. Ultimately, I asked he to install wireshark and capture the network and then send the captured data to me. and boom, there's a distinct reset package sent to stop the normal tcp process by his computer. and turns out it's his anti-virus software putting our site into blacklist.
Also some other customers complaining about the client app being slow and stuff. It was fun.
Serious BofH vibes
why so many columns ?
hy are you not selecting the first and last lette ???   t's driving me craz !!!
Ms SQL server had auto increment IDs in ... 2003 I think when I first started using it. Pretty sure it wasn't a new feature
This sounds so wrong that it smacks of "Yeah that actually happened...".

Early job of mine I worked on a codebase that used bitmasks to determine if things were enabled or not instead of using bit columns in the database. This would require code to run a cron job to check which things needed to be run and then update the bitmask when it completed. You would be shocked how some databases were designed, developed, maintained especially older Oracle or MS SQL Server.
